title: Grades 9-12: American Sign Language
subject: World Languages and Global Workforce Initiatives (2023-)

document.title: Georgia World Languages and Global Workforce Initiatives

27185AFF03E94427BD9740F84B993A85.description: Locate and use resources in the target language, such as individuals and organizations accessible through the community.

BE149E8119104B1FAA9D483EFC5D2199.description: Illustrate how the target language and culture studied are evident in and through the media, entertainment, and technology.

BFE9AC75DB8B487193A86F30BC25BD60.description: Develop and apply target language skills and cultural knowledge beyond the classroom setting for recreational, educational, and occupational purposes.

BEFF889D99C24CA593ABE3137210E457.description: Students develop and apply target language skills and cultural knowledge beyond the classroom setting for recreational, educational, and occupational purposes.

63CEE2DE72364CBC8316059E20325B67.description: Understand the impact of major current events on the target culture.

257552F2849D4686968B4AC277656F42.description: Give information regarding major current events of the target culture.

5FF5326A20D84B819256DE12CDC16BA5.description: Students identify current events of the target culture.

C3E9A8214D1240A0A8FD8CDF5E5AF8D9.description: Use level-appropriate idiomatic expressions and slang in the target language (e.g., "loser", "whatever", train-gone-finish).

E6D5F45EF7B94796B682E2363E42E420.description: Compare vocabulary usage and structural patterns of the target language with English (e.g., conjugation of verbs and time markers)

D2A11F5E59DE4037974AE29938B81ECD.description: Students develop a better understanding of the English language through a study of the target language.

8799C1E317104F32901D49CA7F91B295.description: Compare and contrast social conventions of the target culture with the student(s)' own culture (e.g., family dynamics, deaf child/deaf parents, deaf child/hearing parents).

B4E8F821A72B43DFBB4BCD254693AD2A.description: Students demonstrate an understanding of similarities and differences between the culture studied and the students' own culture(s).

AF8DEC42B19046219ADC23C512EBFF38.description: Relate information acquired in other subjects, such as the use of technology.

6F7D9F4A4DF4491B8C96C9D0F89E610A.description: Give examples of historical perspectives of American Sign Language (e.g., French influence on ASL, Milan Conference, A.G. Bell and Thomas Minor Gallaudet, and educational environments).

49E3E2164DC34664BC749677D014370A.description: Students use information acquired in the study of the target language and information acquired in other subject areas to reinforce one another.

8EC4F20B35AD4A15B5AC886155F075D2.description: Examine international Deaf communities (e.g., foreign deaf communities and sign languages, international organizations, Deaf Way, World Federation of the Deaf, and Deaf Olympics).

C91F17021A9A41A39CD850AA5ACFDFC7.description: Identify patterns of behavior typically associated with Deaf culture (e.g., Deaf clubs, Deaf sports).

457F2D4C2A8447D8BCBF0D84E8013BE6.description: Participate in real or simulated cultural events (e.g., sign-only meals and activities).

55D0300A29894962A2F9C8A37AFB256A.description: Students understand perspectives, practices, and products of the culture where the target language is used and how they are interrelated.

94DF5593A38B4345ACAE785130B8B725.description: Demonstrate SLPI Survival to Survival+ or ASLPI Level 1.0 to 2.0 Proficiency sign production skills of rehearsed and unrehearsed materials.

104B60658CDE4358880C1F745AD14558.description: Students present rehearsed and unrehearsed material in the target language, such as dialogues, skits, and poetry.

33F1DBABC063438C88ACA536B8BBC593.description: Demonstrate SLPI Survival to Survival+ or ASLPI Level 1.0 to 2.0 Proficiency expressive skills.

E1D7FE6E1A9946B88FB19639EFEA6431.description: Give brief, organized signed presentations, using visual and technological support as appropriate.

C3795AEB288849C19F5BA483F714791B.description: Retell main ideas and essential details from level-appropriate ASL materials (e.g., summarizing signed narratives).

42D0DA5C52814E8BA11A680826AC3B5A.description: Students present information using newly acquired vocabulary, phrases, and patterns.

B214D5EB01654C2598D03E57E8563F49.description: Comprehend basic non-manual markers (e.g., facial grammar, mouth phonemes/morphemes).

C517684AC5BA4CB2B966751607B0CDEB.description: Differentiate among statements, questions, and commands (e.g., reciprocal verbs, distributional verbs).

68C0E5E478DE4124AFCF389768E8950F.description: Students will comprehend signed and non-manual markers to understand messages in the target language.

DEB06F28F09748BD89673B4914F64DDC.description: Demonstrate SLPI Survival to Survival+ or ASLPI Level 1.0 to 2.0 Proficiency receptive skills.

49E9728BF1BB4A8C9E0636A6A68D6667.description: Comprehend culturally authentic ASL genres (e.g., poetry, jokes, and stories).

E7457B795AA8489A951A89B7BAC17E73.description: Identify main ideas and essential details while viewing an ASL signed narrative.

3DEFD1F6884E4EB5B90F2241CBD750C4.description: Students understand information on new and familiar topics presented in the target language through a variety of media including authentic narratives and materials.

6DC410F7CD394911A0526D45835ACDA7.description: Demonstrate SLPI Survival to Survival+ or ASLPI Level 1.0 to 2.0 Proficiency in target language exchanges.

87371D4756314B4E8C1720A0FEA8A1B9.description: Use non-manual aspects of ASL to convey and comprehend messages (e.g., eye gaze, and role shifting).

271BE3E4C990499C874900F656471BAD.description: Use simple paraphrasing to convey and comprehend messages (e.g., retelling, and create story from picture stimuli).

F46C15961DF84499ADC3907F30FF864B.description: Initiate, participate in, and close an exchange.

7C1135CCBBD04D378D2BB840E6256F48.description: Students demonstrate skills necessary to initiate, sustain and close exchanges in the target language.

B8F52A7CFCFC471E8A15FF75609E272E.description: Ask questions and provide responses about plans and events (e.g., time markers, listing, and sequencing).

AA2FBB22817F4B3496149B8765D44715.description: Ask questions and provide responses based on topics such as self, others, and immediate environment.

1A2E938F00A54395B8AD1317E5D464A6.description: Give and follow directions and instructions (e.g., locatives, and indexing).

137D05BA00774426A34DD4A25112DBF9.description: Request help and clarification (e.g., how to communicate at a Deaf event).

CA85F0C22A574CB8AB541DCECD766CB1.description: Express feelings and emotions (e.g., varying degrees of intensity, inflection).

1529B98755234CB5BDCB1BC4C4DABA3D.description: Students exchange information in the target language, utilizing cultural references where appropriate.

8B095F1C1AB74CB5817F705426C6789C.description: Identify resources, such as individuals and organizations accessible through the community or the Internet, that provide basic cultural information about the culture studied. (e.g., National Association of the Deaf, Registry of Interpreters for the Deaf, National Black Deaf Advocates, ASL web browser, Deaf Nation, local events).

AC3F65E035EE489BA427A0F49C162B8B.description: Identify examples of the target language and the culture studied that are evident in and through media, entertainment, and technology (Vlogs, ASL movies, careers requiring sign language skill).

AFDB5ADBC9D44FD2A2C730933C129591.description: Students identify situations and resources in which the target language skills and cultural knowledge may be applied beyond the classroom setting for recreational, educational, and occupational purposes.

22B510234CB84F13B2B1B05EC19F1C03.description: Understand the impact of current events of the target culture (e.g., outcomes of Deaf President Now, No Child Left Behind, FCC-Video Phone, Americans with Disabilities Act, Miss Deaf America).

DF8301E935214F8C8A7EDCC28741EBC3.description: Give information about current events of target cultures (e.g., Deaf President Now, oral vs. manual).

E2DD4287F8534040A3DD751AC45EBF32.description: Students demonstrate an awareness of current events in the target culture.

FEBBC1A41D2A440BB1F142ED7B3962DE.description: Recognize basic sign parameters and inflectional patterns (e.g., same/different).

1DDF32D23095437FA38F523F5393C792.description: Recognize similarities and differences in English and the target language regarding idioms, slang (e.g., simple translations to /from English and ASL).

B83CDF13F4EA4610B22CE21BDE0C2491.description: Students compare basic elements of the target language to the English language.

15EDD71C7733474CB4ABFE5889ABE7A7.description: Demonstrate an awareness of elements of the students' own culture (e.g., communication and social interaction; other languages in the home, extended family).

1826F0EBCC584403825A20A467DDEEEE.description: Compare patterns of behavior and interaction in the students' own culture with those of the target culture (e.g., phone/TV access; ring signalers, visual noise; proxemics; eye contact; driving; use of interpreters).

CB2DECDDAAF547489B9AFBFBF1C025F7.description: Students demonstrate an understanding of the significance of culture through comparisons between the culture studied and the students' own culture.

2A9BBD19EC7847BC8E5EC81BAD009D85.description: Relate content from other subject areas to topics discussed in the language class (e.g., literature by or for deaf people; appearance of deaf characters in TV drama; sports; sign for and from other countries).

85633D5B371A4E7CB54610F8911DA46B.description: Apply previously learned skills from other subjects, when appropriate to demonstrate knowledge in the target language (e.g., practice math fact drills; English/ASL grammar; famous deaf people; receptive fingerspelling).

098D1237244642CDAA8CBED609EEE34B.description: Demonstrate knowledge of the evolution and spread of American Sign Language (e.g., travels of T.H. Gallaudet; location of residential schools; Martha's Vineyard; Gallaudet University/NTID/CSUN; regional signs).

1E2570493B2E4F1E801548AB1A6B8075.description: Students use information acquired in the study of the target language and information acquired in other subject areas to reinforce one another.

B36AE9303B9847D4B8D7865C435129C3.description: Describe customs and traditions of the culture, such as greetings, celebrations, and courtesies (e.g., name signs, homecoming, deaf/hearing/hard of hearing, deaf only organizations).

13C2E0D3D42748289BD6BD68F5E96D73.description: Identify commonly held viewpoints of the culture (e.g., cultural vs. medical views of deafness, D/d deaf, residential vs. inclusive models of education).

5C728644A9DD4E0FA1979966EE337D4C.description: Demonstrate knowledge of contributions target culture to civilization (e.g., technology; art; theater and plays; sign language/deaf literature, media, games and jewelry).

467ACA08EB5A43E687F7452F6676FFB7.description: Students develop an awareness of perspectives, practices, and products of the cultures where the target language is used.

087944EBD2824A66A88354A8EAA122F2.description: Demonstrate comprehension of rehearsed material. (videotape as well as live performance)

F2F32D31838F409FA5941744DD51DDE5.description: Demonstrate SLPI Novice + to Survival and ASLPI Level I to I.5 proficiency skills in presenting rehearsed material (e.g., ABC/number stories, skits, assigned topics).

919B54D40B2240C9AFF59728A0A4C16B.description: Students present brief, rehearsed material in the target language, such as dialogues, skits, and poetry.

B1D2F31E0A80452C8FC8B923B7F5EDCF.description: Demonstrate SLPI Novice + to Survival and ASLPI Level I to 1.5 proficiency expressive skills.

16EFD50D107D4F1590C36B442DC61280.description: Present personal narratives (e.g., family tree, house description).

0657B304A3FD47CF9B5B6B7FF6F8DF06.description: Present informational narratives (e.g., calendar, sports, weather).

58E90562E18D416C959C8A3EFE7DF535.description: Students present information that contains a variety of vocabulary, phrases, and patterns.

13FE3E374AB94403A029538872B32DA6.description: Recognize basic non-manual markers (e.g., facial grammar, mouth phonemes/morphemes).

7FAAAF6A83414964ADEADBEABF7835B7.description: Differentiate among statements, questions, and commands (e.g., yes/no, WH, rhetorical questions, commands).

A70AF9D9DE0043AD9F65088251B6B8D3.description: Students will comprehend signed and non-manual markers to understand simple messages in the target language.

7A62C3177ED84D9E81D249304711AB02.description: Demonstrate SLPI Novice+ to Survival and ASLPI Level 1 to 2 proficiency receptive skills.

4C5B2C94F64F4BAEA1CB5008F14EF19A.description: Understand simple instructions, such as classroom procedures.

20336063EC494FE4B198E5A8FA74D2CC.description: Comprehend simple culturally authentic ASL genres (e.g., ABC and number stories and poetry).

FFD01120B83F44118832D26531F3C4DF.description: Identify main ideas and some details, while viewing an ASL signed narrative.

7F8AF2269333498E8A34D0D91DFCB768.description: Students demonstrate an understanding of the target language through a variety of media and based on topics such as self, family, school, etc.

F1B1896FAD0348148F36DE3EDD0D2E2E.description: Demonstrates SLPI Novice + to Survival or ASLPI Level 1 to 2 proficiency.

F57DEA9A0A62473CBBAB84D50398D4E0.description: Initiate, participate in, and close a brief exchange (e.g., turn taking and dialogue).

8D385F0906564CA88AAC0D66D7759078.description: Students demonstrate skills necessary to sustain exchanges in the target language.

67FD3EBC56C24FFFBFC3F1094AE7B15D.description: Use sequenced information meaningfully (e.g., telling time, days of the week, months, seasons, expressive fingerspelling, numbers 0 -100).

2E427CD5EAE845309E5873F65F5CA138.description: Ask questions and provide responses based suggested topics (e.g., yes/no and wh- questions).

E51D3A464DFD4C30B19AED7F992D3039.description: Follow and give simple directions (e.g., use of space, far/near, left/right).

D5A4ADFD2C4D435CAD07C64DAFECB2D4.description: Give simple descriptions (e.g., introduction to size and shape specifiers, classifiers, adjectives).

AD88E3E04CCD406ABC201FE39BC02E43.description: Make simple requests (e.g., basic directional verbs, stand/sit, don't mind).

1862E179FCDC439480A469CBEB8E4878.description: Express like/dislike and agreement /disagreement (e.g., yes, no, maybe, negation, want/don't want).

65AA768663F24A0897087AC565D84EC8.description: Sign basic greetings, introductions, farewells and expressions of courtesy (e.g., eye gaze, turn taking, please and thank you).

8338A11ED32246448181A88D950BFFC9.description: Produce and recognize appropriate attention-getting behaviors (eg., hand wave, shoulder tap).

9EE30C21520443F2BE82CEAA54DE8D01.description: Produce gestures, handshapes, movements, facial expressions and pantomime. (e.g., marked and unmarked handshapes, emotions).

F9BF0A0D2416455BB6FE36EC79CB73BF.description: Students exchange simple information in the target language, utilizing cultural references where appropriate.
